009package imagingbook.common.geometry.moments;
010
011import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
012import imagingbook.common.math.Complex;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * Naive implementation of Flusser's complex invariant moments [1]. See Sec.
017 * 8.6.5 (Eq. 8.51 - 8.54) of [2] for additional details.
018 * This abstract class defines static methods only.
019 * </p>
020 * <p>
021 * [1] J. Flusser, B. Zitova, and T. Suk. "Moments and Moment Invariants in
022 * Pattern Recognition". John Wiley and Sons (2009). 
023 * <br>
024 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
025 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
026 * </p>
027 * 
028 * @author WB
029 * @version 2022/11/17
030 */
031public abstract class FlusserMoments {
032        
033        private FlusserMoments() {}
034        
035        /** Length of moment vector returned by {@link #getInvariantMoments(Iterable)}. */
036        public static final int N = 11; // 11 moment invariants
037        
038        /**
039         * Calculates and returns a vector of 11 invariant moments
040         * for the specified set of 2D points.
041         * 
042         * @param points a set of 2D points
043         * @return the vector of invariant moments
044         */
045        public static double[] getInvariantMoments(Iterable<Pnt2d> points) {
046                Complex c11 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 1, 1);
047                Complex c12 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 1, 2);
048                Complex c21 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 2, 1);
049                Complex c20 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 2, 0);
050                Complex c22 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 2, 2);
051                Complex c30 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 3, 0);
052                Complex c31 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 3, 1);
053                Complex c40 = getScaleNormalizedMoment(points, 4, 0);
054                
055                double p1 = c11.getRe(); 
056                double p2 = c21.multiply(c12).getRe();
057                double p3 = c20.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getRe();
058                double p4 = c20.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getIm();
059                double p5 = c30.multiply(c12.pow(3)).getRe();
060                double p6 = c30.multiply(c12.pow(3)).getIm();
061                double p7 = c22.getRe();
062                double p8 = c31.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getRe();
063                double p9 = c31.multiply(c12.pow(2)).getIm();
064                double p10 = c40.multiply(c12.pow(4)).getRe();
065                double p11 = c40.multiply(c12.pow(4)).getIm();
066                
067                return new double[] {p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, p6, p7, p8, p9, p10, p11};
068        }
069        
070        /**
071         * Returns the scale-normalizes complex moment of order (p,q)
072         * for the specified set of 2D points.
073         * 
074         * @param points a set of 2D points
075         * @param p order index p
076         * @param q order index q
077         * @return the moment value
078         */
079        public static Complex getScaleNormalizedMoment(Iterable<Pnt2d> points, int p, int q) {
080                int xS = 0;
081                int yS = 0;
082                int n = 0;
083                for (Pnt2d pnt : points) {
084                        xS = xS + pnt.getXint();
085                        yS = yS + pnt.getYint();
086                        n++;
087                }
088                
089                double a = n;
090                double xc = xS / n;
091                double yc = yS / n;
092                Complex sum = new Complex(0, 0);
093                for (Pnt2d pnt : points) {
094                        double x = pnt.getX() - xc;
095                        double y = pnt.getY() - yc;
096                        Complex z1 = (x == 0.0 && y == 0 && p == 0) ? 
097                                                        Complex.ZERO : new Complex(x, y).pow(p);        // beware: 0^0 is undefined!
098                        Complex z2 = (x == 0.0 && y == 0 && q == 0) ? 
099                                                        Complex.ZERO : new Complex(x, -y).pow(q);
100                        sum = sum.add(z1.multiply(z2));
101                }
102                checkForNaN(sum);
103                return sum.multiply(1.0 / Math.pow(a, 0.5 * (p + q) + 1));
104        }
105        
106        private static void checkForNaN(Complex z) {
107                if (z.isNaN()) {
108                        throw new RuntimeException("NaN encountered in complex quantity");
109                }
110        }
111        
112}
